The most underrated of Bruckner's masterpieces. And yet its his most original symphony. This with the 9th
were the only two symphonies of Bruckner that another Bernstein loved and recorded. Some of the great film score composers for Blockbuster films . In the past Alfred Newman in the past . And the likes of John Williams
would of or will tell you how much they are indebited to Bruckner.
In this symphony it is fun to suss out some of these. I will give you two for a start . Then try and find some more
and you will. The sonata form second movement's main theme is the main theme for Alfred Newman's " Song
of Benadette" Nine minutes into the opening movement think of the main theme of Maurice Jarre's " Lawrence of
Arabia" And carry on from there.
The second movement is near heaven for me. BUT with the chorale coda of the first movement with more than
thirty modulations we are into Bach territory. What does amuse me is that Hans Zimmer doesn't rate Bruckner.
May I suggest to Mr Zimmer that his finest film score music Chevaliers De Sangreal from " The Da Vinci Code" has
more than a resemblance to some of Bruckner's final notes he composed before dying without completing
his 9th symphony. The minimalism before the coda we hear in the completed versions.

text: I’ve performed much of the great romantic orchestral repertoire. There are a few composers whose output I do not enjoy. the ninth. Although he could play the whole of the eighth on piano without a score!

author: @alger3041
text:
Jeremy, I listened to and watched your little commentary on the Bruckner Sixth Symphony.

As I am actually in the process of writing an essay on the work, as assistance to
a close friend who happens to be a conductor of community orchestras, and is
preparing a performance of it, I thought that I would share my thoughts on the
work with you, being that (1) I have written numerous essays on various works
of this sort, (2) I happen to be a long time member and supporter of Carnegie
Hall, and (3) I find myself in disagreement with one or two points that you make
in your video.

Much of my differences should come out in the essay which at this writing I have completed presenting my thoughts on the first three movements with only the last
remaining to be done.  But I will suggest up front that contrary to your statement
that the first movement of this work may be the most complicated that Bruckner
ever wrote - I rather consider that this symphony as a whole is one of his most
straightforward - I find it one of the easiest to follow, its purpose and agenda
are both especially clear - I rather have difficulty with some of the others that
seem labyrinthine to me - notably the Seventh, so highly esteemed, refuses
to reveal its secrets at my end, but I will sum all this up by stating that we all
hear musical works in our own individual manner, critical and popular appraisal
not withstanding.  Each of us have to undertake our own listening to decide for
ourselves what is valuable to us and what is not, and we can only make informed
decisions of this nature with a degree of listening experience.

Should you wish to write me back, it might be best to use my e-mail address.

Sincerely,

William Zucker
w.zucker57@gmail.com

author: @花田ミサト
text:
Composed by Joseph Anton Bruckner
Symphony No. 6 in A major

　BBC Symphony Orchestra
　Conductor: Otto Klemperer

　Broadcast recording at Maida Vale Studio 1, London, 1961

　*Klemperer was not limited to the symphonies of his mentor Mahler, but also placed great importance on the symphonies of Bruckner, who was also Mahler's predecessor. He was apparently somewhat annoyed by the fact that EMI's famous producer Walter Legg had rejected his proposals to record Bruckner's 6th Symphony and other symphonies early on, claiming that they were not yet "popular" enough. The stereo recording was finally made in November of 1964, after Legg's retirement. The performance of the powerful final movement in particular, the Adagio with its rather fast tempo but deep moat, and the symphony's organic unity as a symphony are few, but it is a lovely work with the theme of "playing with sound," which is rare for Bruckner.
